title: Study Says Flu Virus Remains In Refrigerated Raw Milk For Up To 5 Days - NDTV Food
summary:
Flu Virus Found to Survive in Refrigerated Raw Milk for Up to 5 Days

Publication Date: August 29, 2024
Source: NDTV

A recent study from Stanford University reveals that the influenza virus can remain infectious in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days, raising concerns amid outbreaks of bird flu.

  • The flu virus H1N1 PR8 can survive in raw milk at refrigeration temperatures.
  • More than 14 million Americans consume raw milk annually, which is marketed as a healthier alternative to pasteurized milk.
  • The FDA has linked raw milk to over 200 illness outbreaks, highlighting significant health risks.
  • Flu virus RNA can remain detectable in raw milk for at least 57 days, posing challenges for food safety assessments.
  • Monitoring systems need improvement as bird flu spreads among livestock.
“This work highlights the potential risk of avian influenza transmission through consumption of raw milk and the importance of milk pasteurization.” - Alexandria Boehm, Senior Author

The findings of this research emphasize significant health risks associated with raw milk consumption, particularly in light of ongoing bird flu infections in cattle.
newTitle: Flu Virus Found to Survive in Refrigerated Raw Milk for Up to 5 Days

Bolster efforts to end TB in WHO South-East Asia Region - World Health Organization
summary:
Bolster efforts to end TB in WHO South-East Asia Region

Publication Date: Not specified Source: WHO South-East Asia Regional Office

The World Health Organization has urged member countries in the South-East Asia Region to enhance efforts to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) by emphasizing multi-sectoral strategies at the political level. This includes focusing on socio-economic factors affecting TB and leveraging new technologies.

  • In 2023, a record 3.8 million people started TB treatment in the region.
  • The death toll from TB decreased to 583,000 in 2023, down from a peak of 763,000 in 2021.
  • The region is still responsible for 45% of the global TB burden with over 5 million new cases in 2023.
  • Efforts must be made to ensure equitable access to TB treatment and preventive services, especially for vulnerable populations.
“It is time to push the pedal on the momentum built collectively by the Member countries of the Region in efforts towards ending TB.” - Saima Wazed, Regional Director, WHO South-East Asia Region

In conclusion, there is an urgent need for increased collaboration and funding to address the TB crisis in South-East Asia, emphasizing that no one should be left behind in the global effort to eradicate this disease.
newTitle: Bolster Efforts to End Tuberculosis in South-East Asia

summary:
Bengaluru Sees Increase In Flu-Like Symptoms, Respiratory Infections, Tips To Stay Safe

Date: Unknown | Source: Unknown

Bengaluru is witnessing a surge in flu-like symptoms and respiratory infections due to seasonal changes. Health experts cite cooler temperatures and increased indoor activity as contributing factors.

  • The winter weather has led to an increase in illnesses such as seasonal flu, viral bronchitis, and respiratory allergies.
  • Dust, mould, and indoor pollutants are exacerbating respiratory symptoms.
  • Health experts recommend various precautions to stay safe this winter.

title: Are plant-based milk truly healthy or overhyped? - Mathrubhumi English
summary:
Are Plant-Based Milks Truly Healthy or Overhyped?

Publication Date: New Delhi

New research suggests that popular plant-based milk alternatives such as oat, almond, and soy milk may lack essential nutritional components compared to cow’s milk. The University of Copenhagen study indicates that processing methods can compromise protein quality and create potentially harmful compounds.

  • The popularity of plant-based milks has increased, but they may be nutritionally inadequate compared to cow's milk.
  • Extensive processing, including ultra-high temperature treatments, diminishes protein quality and reduces essential amino acids.
  • Researchers found harmful compounds like acrylamide in certain plant-based beverages, raising potential health risks over time.
  • Despite being eco-friendly options, these drinks may not offer the same benefits as cow's milk.
“Plant-based drinks cannot replace cow’s milk in terms of proper nutrition,” said Professor Marianne Nissen Lund.

The findings highlight a need for consumers to be cautious about the nutritional value of plant-based milks and seek alternatives that can meet dietary needs.
newTitle: Are Plant-Based Milks Truly Healthy or Overhyped?

Nutritionist reveals ‘healthy’ foods you need to steer clear of - The Indian Express
summary:
Nutritionist reveals ‘healthy’ foods you need to steer clear of

Date: (Publication date not provided)

Source: Indianexpress.com

In today’s age, choosing healthy food can be overwhelming due to conflicting information online. A nutritionist investigates the safety of popular 'health foods'.

  • Commercial foods labeled as diet or low-calorie may not be trustworthy without knowledge of ingredients.
  • Dark chocolate may be healthier than milk chocolate due to less sugar and higher antioxidants.
  • Grilling meats at high temperatures can be carcinogenic; lean meats are recommended in soups or boiled.
  • Low fat yogurts often contain added sugars and calories; homemade yogurt is a better option.
  • Artificial sweeteners can cause digestive issues and may harm kidneys if consumed in excess.
  • Moderation is crucial, and a varied diet can help meet nutritional needs.
“In my opinion, any commercial food claiming it is a diet or a low-calorie food is a scam.” - Arooshi Aggarwal, Nutritionist

The article advises caution with commercial health foods and emphasizes the importance of understanding what we consume to maintain health.
newTitle: Nutritionist reveals ‘healthy’ foods you need to steer clear of

title: High Cholesterol Causes: 5 Risk Factors of Excessive LDL Plaque Formation In Heart Arteries - TheHealthSite
summary:
High Cholesterol Causes: 5 Risk Factors of Excessive LDL Plaque Formation In Heart Arteries

Publication Date: Not specified
Source: The Health Site

The article discusses high cholesterol, particularly high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL), which is a significant risk for cardiovascular health. It outlines the top five risk factors contributing to LDL plaque formation in heart arteries.

Key Points

  • Unhealthy Diet: Diets high in saturated and trans fats can raise LDL levels.
  • Not Exercising Regularly: Sedentary lifestyle increases cholesterol levels.
  • Excessive Weight or Obesity: Obesity correlates with high LDL and lower HDL cholesterol levels.
  • Genetic Contribution: Familial hypercholesterolemia influences cholesterol levels from a young age.
  • Excessive Smoking: Smoking contributes to high cholesterol and reduces HDL.

Notable Quotes

“Regular check-ups and blood tests are essential for monitoring cholesterol.”

Taking control of risk factors can help manage cholesterol and improve heart health.
newTitle: High Cholesterol Causes: 5 Risk Factors of Excessive LDL Plaque Formation In Heart Arteries

Flu Virus Found To Survive In Refrigerated Raw Milk: Study - Free Press Journal
summary:
Flu Virus Found To Survive In Refrigerated Raw Milk: Study

Date: Sunday, December 15, 2024

Source: Free Press Journal

The study conducted by Stanford University reveals that the influenza virus can remain infectious in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days. This raises concerns about the potential health risks associated with raw milk consumption.

  • The flu virus H1N1 PR8 remained infectious in raw milk at refrigeration temperatures.
  • More than 14 million Americans consume raw milk annually despite health risks from pathogens.
  • The FDA links raw milk to over 200 outbreaks of serious illnesses.
  • Pasteurization is effective in destroying infectious influenza but not all viral RNA.
  • Flu viruses infect over 40 million people in the U.S. each year, causing significant health issues.
  • Bird flu detection in cattle raises further concerns about transmission through dairy products.
"The persistence of infectious influenza virus in raw milk for days raises concerns about potential transmission pathways." - Mengyang Zhang

The findings stress the importance of pasteurization and monitoring systems to manage food safety, especially amid ongoing bird flu outbreaks.
newTitle: Study Reveals Flu Virus Can Survive in Refrigerated Raw Milk for Days

title: Poliovirus found in wastewater in Spain, Germany and Poland — what you need to know - The Indian Express
summary:
Poliovirus found in wastewater in Spain, Germany and Poland — what you need to know

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Indian Express

In recent months, traces of poliovirus have been found in wastewater in Germany, Spain, and Poland, signaling potential risks for public health and raising alarms for vaccination coverage across Europe.

  • The WHO initiated a global effort to eradicate polio in 1988, achieving a 99% reduction in cases.
  • Polio is a highly contagious disease that can lead to paralysis and death, primarily spread through the faecal-oral route.
  • Despite significant gains in eradication, two countries, Pakistan and Afghanistan, remain endemic.
  • Detection of poliovirus in wastewater can warn healthcare systems of potential outbreaks.
  • Vaccine-derived poliovirus strains can revert to virulent forms if circulation occurs among under-immunised populations.
“The alert triggered by wastewater surveillance systems in Spain, Poland and Germany highlights how wastewater-based surveillance provides public health authorities with another weapon in the fight against infectious diseases.”

The findings underscore the importance of monitoring vaccination coverage and enhancing public health responses to prevent polio's resurgence.
newTitle: Poliovirus Detected in Wastewater Across Europe: Key Insights

title: Are Plant-Based Milks As Healthy As They Seem? Study Reveals Concerns Over Protein Quality And Potential Health Risks - Zee News
summary:
Are Plant-Based Milks As Healthy As They Seem? Study Reveals Concerns Over Protein Quality And Potential Health Risks

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Zee News

Recent research indicates that popular plant-based milks like oat, almond, and soy may not provide the same nutritional benefits as cow's milk, raising concerns about protein quality and potential health risks due to processing methods.

  • The study from the University of Copenhagen indicates that extensive processing may reduce protein quality in plant-based milks.
  • Plant-based milks typically contain less protein compared to cow's milk and may lose essential amino acids during ultra-high temperature (UHT) treatment.
  • Acrylamide, a known carcinogen, was found at low levels in some almond and oat-based drinks, leading to potential health risks over time.
“Plant-based drinks cannot replace cow’s milk in terms of proper nutrition.” - Professor Marianne Nissen Lund

In conclusion, while plant-based milks are popular for their environmental benefits, their nutritional adequacy compared to traditional dairy remains in question.
newTitle: Study Raises Concerns Over Plant-Based Milk: Protein Quality and Health Risks Examined

Feeling lonely? Study says loneliness increases your risk of developing dementia by 31% - Hindustan Times
summary:
Feeling lonely? Study says loneliness increases your risk of developing dementia by 31%

Date: Dec 15, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

A groundbreaking study published in Nature Mental Health finds that loneliness increases the risk of developing dementia by 31%. It emphasizes the severe impact of loneliness on brain health.

  • The study analyzed data from 608,561 individuals worldwide.
  • Loneliness was shown to be a crucial risk factor for dementia, comparable to smoking and lack of exercise.
  • Researchers noted loneliness leads to cognitive decline and is linked to Alzheimer’s disease and vascular dementia.
  • Lack of mental stimulation and chronic stress due to loneliness contribute to the risk of dementia.
  • Loneliness can also lead to mild cognitive problems, indicating early effects before dementia onset.
“This is groundbreaking, as the risk factor of loneliness is similar to other commonly known risk factors for dementia.”

This study highlights the urgent need for addressing loneliness as a public health issue, especially in light of its long-term implications for cognitive health.
newTitle: Study Links Loneliness to Increased Dementia Risk

title: World can expect another zoonotic pandemic: Ex-WHO Director - Yes Punjab
summary:
World Can Expect Another Zoonotic Pandemic, Warns Ex-WHO Director

Date: December 15, 2024 Source: Yes Punjab News

The world can anticipate another pandemic due to virus spillover from animals, according to Mario C.B. Raviglione, former Director of the WHO's Global TB Programme.

  • Raviglione emphasizes the interconnectedness of the world as a key factor for rapid disease spread.
  • He states that many emerging diseases are zoonotic, with potential for new pathogens to emerge from animal species.
  • Recent diseases such as COVID-19, Ebola, and mPox highlight the risks associated with zoonotic diseases.
  • Preparedness for such pandemics is critically low among countries, leading to potential implications for global health.
  • Raviglione suggests the creation of preparedness hubs to enhance early detection and response capabilities.
“Preparedness implies that you need to have the support of laboratories, the support of pharma and biochemical, or the biochemical sector to rapidly develop the test...” - Mario C.B. Raviglione

In conclusion, Raviglione calls for increased investment in pandemic preparedness to prevent disastrous outbreaks.
newTitle: World Can Expect Another Zoonotic Pandemic, Warns Ex-WHO Director

title: Doctor who diagnosed his own Alzheimer’s advises to NEVER ignore these warning signs - The Times of India
Does reduced water intake during winter increase the risk of kidney stones? Doctor explains - Indiatimes.com
summary:
Does Reduced Water Intake During Winter Increase the Risk of Kidney Stones? Doctor Explains

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Indiatimes

As winter approaches, reduced water intake alongside increased consumption of hot drinks may lead to dehydration and an increased risk of kidney stones, according to Dr. Uday Dipakrao Gajare, Consultant Nephrologist.

Introduction

Water is crucial for health, but in winter, people tend to drink less, which can lead to health issues, including dehydration and kidney stones.

Key Points

  • Men should drink at least 3.1 liters of water daily, while women should consume 2.1 liters.
  • Reduced thirst in winter can increase the risk of kidney stones due to concentrated urine.
  • Kidney stones are major health problems characterized by hard deposits in the kidney.
  • Maintaining adequate hydration and diet is essential to prevent kidney stones.

Notable Quotes

“Hydration and salt intake play major roles in their formation.” - Dr. Uday Dipakrao Gajare

Conclusion

To prevent kidney stones in winter, it is essential to maintain hydration, reduce salt, and consume a balanced diet.
newTitle: Does Reduced Water Intake During Winter Increase the Risk of Kidney Stones? Doctor Explains
